te
: shewed unto

to treat & conclude uppon them, for that their comissions

The acte of disadvowance we refused to deli
v
, (as so directed)
onles they wold
unlesse they wold
assent unto an abolition toward
suche
sons
there compatriottes
as were banished and disgraced
for
by them for shewe of

& indevours

tie
, and her [.]
in theise Countries

s and otherwise had
often

p
r
vaile. After long debating and
many
reasons yeilded by us to

tie
, in this pointe they concluded
that if we wold deli
v
the acte to be published it would be
a meanes not only to move the provinces but the townes in
ticulare where the banished
were
had ben
sentenced by course of Justice,
(and w
t

not

judged,) to condiscend to as muche as her Ma

we desired therein to be
doned, and advised them on their
t

of a reciprocall course to gratifye

in the one as she had
freely &
g
gratiously graunted the

suasions

there
so

r

wold

toward

by their ingratitude should be drawen to revoke her

rs
. that her Ma
t
demaund
were no new thing
unto them
but
suche as had ben often urged
unto them
, and ev
r
denyed , or

and
that
their p
r

t
the consaile on o
r
replies were but
devises to win tyme
and that we supposed the Provinc
not to be of their myndes to yeld so
ingratefull requitall to her Ma
tie
for so great & inestimable benefitte
. This and muche more too long to be
writen we deli
v
ed unto them, w
ch
bred in them no altera
on
of
their po
r
pose but rather as to muche to answer us, that they
were bound to see to the saftie of their Countreys, that theise
demandes of her Ma
tie
tended to the overthrowe
thereof
of them
: that they
knewe it did import her Ma
tie
as muche as them to kepe their
Countrys from the Spaynard
to whome if they should yeld
them self
by a peace her Ma
tie
would spedily
knowe
fynde
the want of their allyance: that what soever her Ma
tie
had
bestowed in the succo
r
of them
according to the contracte
should be
duely
repaied and for the
w
ch
she had
sufficient caution
in
remayned on her
hand
and that their
resolutions deli
v

r

had

there
severall
Provinc
. To theise their answers we replied as
ap
tauned

ceeding

This conference ended we de
ted from their assembly w

conclusion

ceive as well by their delayes as by their
speaches & doing

otherwise

as

cor

n

r

t
we have reason by many circumstances to conjecture, that thesmen and people are (as we feare) irrecouverably fallen
from all good affection toward
her Ma
tie
having ben so long suffered to hatche and chereshe the misconceipt
they have had of some
indiscreet
dealing

r

untill on the [ijj]
th

tie

n
to my lodging, fell into speache of what had passed between the States and us in
the last
assemblee
conference
, gave me to under stand as of him selfe
that there had ben
& under

some furder considera

n

taken
by

positi

ch

and doubted not but

Ma
tye
therein suche reasonable satisfaction as might well be requered:
so as we are hereby put in some hope, that they will
yeild to more that they we expected when we de
ted from there assemblie
and therefore did advise us to
cede and to deli
v
suche furder reasons
againe
in writing suche reasons
as we had

to

t
demand
:
whose [.]

r

This
tie
gav
likewise

as a

gave furder advise
that
that we
Trust we fynde theye there hath
ben
Suche as
[.]
have sought to [disprove]
and slander the actions of her
Ma
tie
& her subject
here have dangerously
blowen into the eares of the Comon
people
a [.]
that her Ma
ties
intention, from the beginning hath
ben by indirect & undue meanes (not w
t

made of the Sou
v
aintie &
tection of theise Countreys offered
unto her) to seaze and

was

t
Charge as don by her
comandem
t
. This hath ben sprede by the practise of some
principall
sonnes of theise Countreys suche as doe affecte
the faction of the Frenche, w
ch
is followed here (not w
t
standing
it is [indevoured] to
suade her Ma
tie
and yo
r
LL to
e contrary)
so
en.
ernestly
secuted
under hand, that the comon people
hav
e
ing
nothing els in there mowthes and conceipt
, but that
the
Frenche K.

v

to saye even to
r
o
r
faces that are englishe that they hope
of better assistance and relief from France, then ever they

have had from her Ma

. Moreover there is nothing don in
Englande to
e prejudice of any inhabitant here, but is made
mater to agravate
& inlarge

concept of the people against her
Ma
tie
, as namely
the stay of
some shippes & good
of others
nowe lately
in
made
stayed
by
S
r

(whereof
we have
late
at the instance of the States
we have
writen to yo
r
LL.) is
given out so muche to the disadvantage of her Ma
tie
and
her nation as nothing more. We therefore as well to
incounter this practise as to p
r
vent
furder were whereas in the tyme that I Thomas Wilkes was
lately
here
employed
and had the aqueyntance of many of the best of these
Countreys gentlemen and others
then well affected to her Ma
tie
that wold usually resort
unto me, I dare assure yo
r
L: that not sithence my
being here, they be not (and as I learne they dare
not) repaire unto me, nor any man, unlesse it be
Paul
Buis
kept from all credit and place among them, dare
discouver him self to be englishe.
and therefore
To what head or office theise thing
may com yo
r
LL will
better Judge then we best consider: only for o
r
poore opini
o
to p
r
vent the mischefe that may followe
thereof
of this practis as

ence
